intro: Acaena sericea var. gracilis, commonly known as the slender burrplant, is a low-growing perennial shrub native to New Zealand. It features small, needle-like leaves covered in fine, silky hairs, giving it a soft, fuzzy appearance. The plant produces tiny, spiny fruits that are typically red or brown, containing seeds that are dispersed by animals. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and stream banks. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important component of its native habitat.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena sericea var. gracilis is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the North Island and parts of the South Island. This plant typically grows in coastal areas and on rocky slopes. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in maritime climates. It is a low-growing shrub with distinctive silver-gray foliage.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena sericea var. gracilis was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. This plant has since become naturalized in various habitats across the country. It is commonly found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and forest margins. Its introduction has raised concerns due to its potential for spreading and impacting native ecosystems.
